results.content:
The bar is WAY TO LOW.

Building an app with React + GraphQL + AWS Amplify is conceptually a complex idea.

This course talks to the student at such a beginner level that it doesn't make sense why it covers these topics that NO BEGINNER should even be attempting.

Most of your time will be spent trying not to fall asleep.

results.content: Was a long journey. At the end, satisfaction of having created a working app with App-sync backend. A level of proficiency with JS and familiarity with React is needed to get into the course. Rest, including GraphQL, have been explained well. Overall, a nice introduction to GraphQL, App Sync, Amplify. Should be followed up with other advanced courses as also recommended by the authors. Thanks to both of them for putting together a nice course.

results.content: A lot of content are outdated and many Q&As not responded to for months 6+ months or more. For those React developers, no hooks; only classes. It goes off track to to talk about MongoDB (not even in the course objectives). Stephen only speaks for 5 mins (not seen for the rest of the course; don't be tricked). The Express.js set up of GraphQL was the highlight for me. It's definitely not a complete AWS Amplify course. He only starts using AWS Amplify 75% into the course, some 7 hours in. This course would good a good starter course for those wanting to know about GraphQL, and an introduction of AWS Amplify and AppSync. After completing the course, I have to study more content elsewhere (disappointingly).

results.content: The course is good for those who want to explore serverless solutions using GraphQL. The instructor repeats himself a lot, which can be arguable. Also, the volume is inconsistent. At times, it goes very soft, so hard to hear.

results.content:
The course was structured in a straight forward manner and it gave a decent introduction into the using Amplify with React and GraphQL.

AWS changes constantly and there are numerous courses that are way out of date. There are aspects of this course that are somewhat behind, but all of the commands still worked as expected.

The downside is that this is a very minimal introduction. You are shown how to set up an amplify app that is extremely simple and go from there. There is no discussion of how to update the system once created. There is no discussion of keys or anything beyond the absolute basics of amplify / graphQL /  DynammoDB. For this reason, someone who completes this course is not prepared to build their own app. It would still take hours of doc reading and learning before you could attempt something with even the slightest bit of complexity.

In addition to this, there is a great deal that needs to be done to set up cognito pools and other AWS items that simply are not covered in this tutorial. After learning more about Appsync and Amplify, I have returned twice now to lower the rating. The course is not really acceptable. It is simply not comprehensive enough.

results.content:
Good course.  The instructor is amiable and it was a fun introduction to GraphQL and AppSync.  I appreciated the detailed intro to GraphQL, as it was new to me.

Some criticisms:

* The title is a major misnomer.  It's hardly a "complete guide" -- it's a "get your feet wet" course that mostly focuses on GraphQL and barely scratches the surface of AppSync.

* I would have preferred to see a schema-first approach in the GraphQL tutorial that had us writing SDL, rather than using the code-first approach with verbose Javascript schema definitions.

* I understand it's a basic tutorial on AppSync and DynamoDB, but I would have liked to see sorting and filtering included

* One particularly concerning omission was that of server-side security.  It's one thing to show/hide edit/delete buttons on the client side, but that is just security by obscurity and doesn't prevent a malicious actor from nonetheless submitting those GraphQL queries.  
Authorization in AppSync resolvers should really be covered.

Overall, though, I still really enjoyed the course and hope to see more AWS-related content from Paulo.
results.content_html:
Good course. The instructor is amiable and it was a fun introduction to GraphQL and AppSync. I appreciated the detailed intro to GraphQL, as it was new to me.

Some criticisms:

* The title is a major misnomer. It's hardly a "complete guide" -- it's a "get your feet wet" course that mostly focuses on GraphQL and barely scratches the surface of AppSync.

* I would have preferred to see a schema-first approach in the GraphQL tutorial that had us writing SDL, rather than using the code-first approach with verbose Javascript schema definitions.

* I understand it's a basic tutorial on AppSync and DynamoDB, but I would have liked to see sorting and filtering included

* One particularly concerning omission was that of server-side security. It's one thing to show/hide edit/delete buttons on the client side, but that is just security by obscurity and doesn't prevent a malicious actor from nonetheless submitting those GraphQL queries.
Authorization in AppSync resolvers should really be covered.

Overall, though, I still really enjoyed the course and hope to see more AWS-related content from Paulo.

results.content_html: This course is awesome if you trying to get started with React and AWS Amplify! You'll build a React Blog App using classes, and lifecycle methods.

results.content:
Some issues that I had with the course:
- At a running time of over 11 hours, I expected this course to be a fairly deep dive into AppSync and Amplify CLI. This course is NOT that. Nearly half of the course covers building a GraphQL based application using ExpressJS and other GraphQL libraries, NOT AppSync. To me, this is borderline false advertising. If I wanted to take a course on general GraphQL application development, there are several here on Udemy. This course is supposed to be focused on AppSync

- The example application is very basic to the point of being trivial. A simple blog application is basically the "Hello World" of development courses. Some things that could have been included, but weren't: 

- Authentication beyond just using the basic built in components, for example using Federation with Google or FaceBook
- Permissions/Authorization. Amplify contains a very sophisticated authorization system that grants access to users based on directives in the schema. We see none of that.
- Modifying the resolvers/working with the Velocity templates. It's extremely likely that the default resolvers will not be sufficient for a real world application, and it would be nice to see how to work with the Velocity templates used by Amplify
- Local/Offline Storage
- Amplify Hub/Pub-Sub
- And much more that is not covered. 

Amplify has a huge amount of functionality available, and this course barely scrapes the surface.

- Also, the code in this course is very basic. Any professional JS developer will recognize and recoil at the sloppy code, inconsistent CSS and general lack of quality of the code that we're expected to follow along with. 

I was very disappointed in this course, because I've taken several of Stephane's AWS courses and I've found them to be very high quality, helping me to attain multiple AWS certifications.
results.content_html:
Some issues that I had with the course:
- At a running time of over 11 hours, I expected this course to be a fairly deep dive into AppSync and Amplify CLI. This course is NOT that. Nearly half of the course covers building a GraphQL based application using ExpressJS and other GraphQL libraries, NOT AppSync. To me, this is borderline false advertising. If I wanted to take a course on general GraphQL application development, there are several here on Udemy. This course is supposed to be focused on AppSync

- The example application is very basic to the point of being trivial. A simple blog application is basically the "Hello World" of development courses. Some things that could have been included, but weren't:

- Authentication beyond just using the basic built in components, for example using Federation with Google or FaceBook
- Permissions/Authorization. Amplify contains a very sophisticated authorization system that grants access to users based on directives in the schema. We see none of that.
- Modifying the resolvers/working with the Velocity templates. It's extremely likely that the default resolvers will not be sufficient for a real world application, and it would be nice to see how to work with the Velocity templates used by Amplify
- Local/Offline Storage
- Amplify Hub/Pub-Sub
- And much more that is not covered.

Amplify has a huge amount of functionality available, and this course barely scrapes the surface.

- Also, the code in this course is very basic. Any professional JS developer will recognize and recoil at the sloppy code, inconsistent CSS and general lack of quality of the code that we're expected to follow along with.

I was very disappointed in this course, because I've taken several of Stephane's AWS courses and I've found them to be very high quality, helping me to attain multiple AWS certifications.

This course felt underwhelming, but it might be good for someone who just wants to scratch the surface. I was expecting to learn about creating many-to-many relationships, creating lambda functions and having some functions trigger post-confirmation or something along those lines, but I saw none of that.

I can tell these instructors know a lot the topic, but they didn't show it as the course left much to be desired. Perhaps there will be a part 2 added to this course or created as a separate course. If so, I'll take a look at it as well.

results.content:
I wanna thank you Paulo for the work he done for NodeJS and MongoDb section. Nevertheless it is strange that more the 50% course time I should watching in details nodeJs and mongoDB setup and work. I like Idea to have comprising "common" graphQL approach with AppSync. From my point of view NodeJS should be cut off significantly and MongoDB should not be part of that course at all as work with databases is different and rather comprehensive topic at all. I would recommend to keep about 10-15% of nodeJS Section and make standalone course something as "Introduction in nodeJS and MongoDb". In general, as experienced nodeJS developer, I liked very much as Paulo explains step by step setup and developing server on NodeJS with MongoDb.
Thank you.

results.content:
1. Instructor doesn't appear to be active in Q&A.
2. Doesn't follow React development best practices.
3. It is very difficult to follow the instructor. He talks around too much, not concise at all. I had to put the video in 1.5x.
4. No mention of AWS Amplify Admin UI
5. Doesn't show how to modify the initial schema.
6. Nothing about deploying to production nor CI/CD implementation.

Sadly this is, by far, one of of the worst courses I've ever taken on Udemy! Very far away from Stephane's courses quality.

results.content: There are several inaccuracies in the instructions. Should update the course.
results.content_html: There are several inaccuracies in the instructions. Should update the course.

results.content: This is not app sync course !!! Don’t be deceived by title. In this course there is maybe around 6 minutes about appsync rest is you following a bad tutorial in react.   The good parts:  the introduction to graphql is good. If you want just graphql intro than that optional part is probably the best part of the whole thing. THE BAD: 1) author has some random ideas that are never explored like adding mongodb to do one small bit next ending the mongodb story. Appsync is really not showcased at all. You have just generation of project and that is it. Author doesn’t show you how to add models or extend app. No normal useful things. 2) there is no production ready info. You can’t skip most important part of the skill in teaching. 3)blog is very badly designed, in the course you are making a blog app that uses the api by sending ids to backend. There is no security involved so anyone can send any request with any ids. That is a recipe for disaster. 4) all the important and interesting bits of appsync are avoided like fire. 5) author talks about some android app we will be making. I understand reuse of videos but ffs edit out some bits. If you make a typo and you are fixing it live that is fine. But if you made a typo and you are adding some text to later fix it. Just edit it out.  Please add production info about appsync. Like how would you go about moving the app into production. How would you go about adding model or relation to a different table etc. how would you manage this project in a team of 2-3 people.  Things that are useful rather than beat on dead horse  of blog tutorial. All the info I’m asking would mean extra 1h  of videos but would make this course worthwhile.

I understand reuse of videos but ffs edit out some bits. If you make a typo and you are fixing it live that is fine. But if you made a typo and you are adding some text to later fix it. Things that are useful rather than beat on dead horse of blog tutorial. All the info I’m asking would mean extra 1h of videos but would make this course worthwhile.

The Optional GraphQL section was really well explained. However, The rest of sections had very little knowledge about Amplify which I expected. It was more towards React Frontend developing.

Also the optional GraphQL section was in Express and the way it was explained had no connection with the way it was explained in React.

Overall, this is a course just for having a good idea. Very far away from courses which Stephane teaches.

results.content:
Alright, this is a pretty good hands-on project-based course. It even looks like a GraphQL side lesson is put in that's from another course as a bonus. 

That's a plus and a negative. You are not told the differences of going through those different routes. Not only that you aren't given more in-depth examples of how to change the GraphQL queries in order to change the app from a blog to something else. 

Lastly, while the final app is cool fundamental features like search aren't explained how to implement in this tutorial series. It's a blog yet features like adding an image also aren't shared. 

It's a good course but for beginners, there is still some "figure it out on your own" spots.
results.content_html:
Alright, this is a pretty good hands-on project-based course. It even looks like a GraphQL side lesson is put in that's from another course as a bonus.

That's a plus and a negative. You are not told the differences of going through those different routes. Not only that you aren't given more in-depth examples of how to change the GraphQL queries in order to change the app from a blog to something else.

Lastly, while the final app is cool fundamental features like search aren't explained how to implement in this tutorial series. It's a blog yet features like adding an image also aren't shared.

It's a good course but for beginners, there is still some "figure it out on your own" spots.

results.content: Great course, I highly recommend this course if you want to learn GraphQL and AWS Appsync/Amplify. I tried to develop some features before looking at the next video to compare a bit what the instructor had in mind and learned more this way than only following what he did. One star get deducted because I think there is still room to make a more detailed course on this topic, maybe including designing the schema and how to make custom queries etc. but overall a very good course. Thank You!

results.content: Being brand new to React, AWS, and GraphQL - I really enjoyed the course!  Surprisingly, it was the Optional GraphQL tutorial that I found most beneficial.  Although it was presented using mongodb instead of dynamodb, the lesson proved to transfer the knowledge effortlessly and really did help me get a grasp on the overall concept.  (Lesson 40 Could be updated for future users - MLab is rolled into Mongo at the time of this review... the UI & terminology was quite a bit different and I had a few trial and errors before getting everything connected.) All in All, very beneficial... Thanks Paulo!
results.content_html: Being brand new to React, AWS, and GraphQL - I really enjoyed the course! Surprisingly, it was the Optional GraphQL tutorial that I found most beneficial. Although it was presented using mongodb instead of dynamodb, the lesson proved to transfer the knowledge effortlessly and really did help me get a grasp on the overall concept. (Lesson 40 Could be updated for future users - MLab is rolled into Mongo at the time of this review... the UI & terminology was quite a bit different and I had a few trial and errors before getting everything connected.) All in All, very beneficial... Thanks Paulo!

results.content:
The content was pretty good but I didn't like the videos that much. There was a lot of basic code errors - even syntax errors that could be prevented by using an IDE. While testing the user functionality, Paul was using a single browser and was logging in and out all the time, why didn't he use incognito window or a different browser?

Also, when starting a new course it would be good to clean your AWS environment to avoid your own confusion when going through the DynamoDB tables and such.

The React app structure - when it came to components it all seemed to be really rushed - which I don't think is a good example for students (Storing the Like logic in DisplayPosts component). 

Finally, just hiding the buttons to restrict the functionality for the user is actually not right - there would have to be permissions on the mutations etc. I am not saying that it should be covered in the course, but at least mentioned that there needs to be an extra effort before launching anything like this app in production.

To summarise - I really enjoyed the content and I'm excited to build a new app using AppSync and Amplify. So thank you for that.
results.content_html:
The content was pretty good but I didn't like the videos that much. There was a lot of basic code errors - even syntax errors that could be prevented by using an IDE. While testing the user functionality, Paul was using a single browser and was logging in and out all the time, why didn't he use incognito window or a different browser?

Also, when starting a new course it would be good to clean your AWS environment to avoid your own confusion when going through the DynamoDB tables and such.

The React app structure - when it came to components it all seemed to be really rushed - which I don't think is a good example for students (Storing the Like logic in DisplayPosts component).

Finally, just hiding the buttons to restrict the functionality for the user is actually not right - there would have to be permissions on the mutations etc. I am not saying that it should be covered in the course, but at least mentioned that there needs to be an extra effort before launching anything like this app in production.

To summarise - I really enjoyed the content and I'm excited to build a new app using AppSync and Amplify. So thank you for that.

results.content: I think he does an excellent job teaching.  He would get another star if he would update the course, at least with comments and current instructions. results.content:
Pretty disappointed with the course. 
I expected a deep review of aws appsync and amplify with recommendations or best practices.
I would have no problem with the optional 5 hours section of graphql if the other sections were good enough... however they barely scratch the surface of what amplify might do.

The course need to specify, clearly, that it is an introduction to these technologies is not a guide and even less a complete one.

The course has multiple ways to improve, for instance, each section or video might have a link to the code updated to each part. That thing would greatly improve the slow pace of the videos allowing the student to focus in the parts that one might want.
results.content_html:

results.content: Took this course Jan 2021. It was really informative for AppSync and how Amplify works. It's great to see how AWS ties all the data together through the CLI. Very cool stuff. This is definitely need-to-know technology if you want to create responsive apps with AWS and React. Loved it!
results.content_html: Took this course Jan 2021. It was really informative for AppSync and how Amplify works. It's great to see how AWS ties all the data together through the CLI. Very cool stuff. This is definitely need-to-know technology if you want to create responsive apps with AWS and React. Loved it!

results.content: Highly recommended!!!
results.content_html: Highly recommended!!!

results.content:
The course project did not validate user input on the server side. It is totally insecure and the 'rules' are maintained completely in the client. This is an unacceptable practice and not even mentioning this issue to users is extremely irresponsible.

The GraphQL section was pretty good though. (This was not a graphql course!)
results.content_html:

results.content:
Très bon cours, accessible pour les débutants.
Permet de découvrir le pouvoir d'AWS simplement via un projet simple et qui peut servir de point de départ pour certains.
Je recommande

results.content:
I was able to get a basic knowledge of AWS AppSync and Amplify. I think this course is quite fit for me to understand them.

It seems that there are many similar explanation (just different objects)  in GraphQL lessons.

I felt little uncomfortable about peculiar indentation of coding demonstration even it is not problem but just feel...
results.content_html:
I was able to get a basic knowledge of AWS AppSync and Amplify. I think this course is quite fit for me to understand them.

It seems that there are many similar explanation (just different objects) in GraphQL lessons.

I felt little uncomfortable about peculiar indentation of coding demonstration even it is not problem but just feel...

results.content: more than half of the course is about GraphQL with express-graphql. AppSync/Amplify coverage sounds basic (initial schema never modified, use of API Key, ...), basically it is just about 'amplify api/auth/hosting add'
results.content_html: more than half of the course is about GraphQL with express-graphql. AppSync/Amplify coverage sounds basic (initial schema never modified, use of API Key, ...), basically it is just about 'amplify api/auth/hosting add'

results.content: I wish this class would have gone deeper. The app we built here used outdated/poor React patterns and left a lot of questions when thinking about how to build a production ready AppSync app.
results.content_html: I wish this class would have gone deeper. The app we built here used outdated/poor React patterns and left a lot of questions when thinking about how to build a production ready AppSync app.

results.content:
I'm really excited and grateful to you. Before starting my programming knowledge about was updated and I thought that I couldn't accomplish it but I achieved it.

Thank you so much... that was wonderful!

results.content:
The project is an entry level project. The main focus is on React implementation and provides only basic knowledge about AppSync. There isn't any information about more advanced topics like: writing custom resolver, working with different data sources and Lambda functions. Probably a second project that is focused primarily on AppSync and Amplify should be part to the course.
The code is not formatted well, that doesn't make good impression.
results.content_html:
The project is an entry level project. The main focus is on React implementation and provides only basic knowledge about AppSync. There isn't any information about more advanced topics like: writing custom resolver, working with different data sources and Lambda functions. Probably a second project that is focused primarily on AppSync and Amplify should be part to the course.
The code is not formatted well, that doesn't make good impression.

results.content: Great overview of AppSync and GraphQL! Doesn't go into too much depth on Amplify, but since you use it hands-on all the time it's not really necessary. Do note that this is not a Stephane course though. Paulo is good, so not really a problem, but I thought this course was a cooperation.
results.content_html: Great overview of AppSync and GraphQL! Doesn't go into too much depth on Amplify, but since you use it hands-on all the time it's not really necessary. Do note that this is not a Stephane course though. Paulo is good, so not really a problem, but I thought this course was a cooperation.

results.content: Great course!  Would like a bit more on manually creating appsync endpoints, velocity templates, and pipeline functions.  Maybe an advanced course.
results.content_html: Great course! Would like a bit more on manually creating appsync endpoints, velocity templates, and pipeline functions. Maybe an advanced course.

results.content:
The Lecturer had some mistakes inside the course, also not using the most recent ReactJs code.
However, he provided a good basic knowledge of the course content :)
results.content_html:
The Lecturer had some mistakes inside the course, also not using the most recent ReactJs code.
However, he provided a good basic knowledge of the course content :)

results.content: The MongoDB platform has changed. The UI some of the connections are different. Screens definitely need updating. I dug my way through it, but definitely out of date.
results.content_html: The MongoDB platform has changed. The UI some of the connections are different. Screens definitely need updating. I dug my way through it, but definitely out of date.

results.content:
Nice course and very well done by Paulo. His clear and encouraging style keeps you focused. I see the passion in his teaching. 

I was here not for the hands-on coding part but mainly to grasp GraphQL, AppSync and Amplify side of things along with a bit of React. 

Perhaps, the repeated code constructs could've been copy/pasted rather than typing online. The AppSync part could've been expanded more.
results.content_html:
Nice course and very well done by Paulo. His clear and encouraging style keeps you focused. I see the passion in his teaching.

I was here not for the hands-on coding part but mainly to grasp GraphQL, AppSync and Amplify side of things along with a bit of React.

Perhaps, the repeated code constructs could've been copy/pasted rather than typing online. The AppSync part could've been expanded more.

results.content:
Loved the GraphQL part of the course. The AppSync and Amplify sections are very hands-on.
I haven't found the css for the Blog exercise, so I had to do it myself. The styles were not auto-included in the newest Cognito log in page too, but I was able to find them in an answer from a student in the Q&A section.
results.content_html:
Loved the GraphQL part of the course. The AppSync and Amplify sections are very hands-on.
I haven't found the css for the Blog exercise, so I had to do it myself. The styles were not auto-included in the newest Cognito log in page too, but I was able to find them in an answer from a student in the Q&A section.
